qas.question: How did Disco Eye-Cued system benefit DJs?

answers.text: visual cue to DJs mixing the records

qas.question: How did Disco Eye-Cued sysems differ from LPs?

answers.text: only contain one track each side

qas.question: When was the Disco Eye-Cued System developed?
What were direct to disc recordings expected to product?
When were 'half speed' and 'digitally remastered' recordings being released?

context: Also in the <a4_0>late 1970s<a4_0/>, "direct-to-disc" records were produced, aimed at an audiophile niche market. These completely bypassed the use of magnetic tape in favor of <a3_0>a "purist" transcription<a3_0/> directly to the master lacquer disc. Also during this period, half-speed mastered and "original master" records were released, using expensive state-of-the-art technology. A further <a2_0>late 1970s<a2_0/> development was the Disco Eye-Cued system used mainly on Motown 12-inch singles released between 1978 and 1980. The introduction, drum-breaks, or choruses of a track were indicated by widely separated grooves, giving a <a0_0>visual cue to DJs mixing the records<a0_0/>. The appearance of these records is similar to an LP, but they <a1_0>only contain one track each side<a1_0/>.
